required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Performance, Usability, and Reliability of a Novel Device for Continuous Collection of Physiological Data
clinical_study.official_title: A Study to Evaluate the Performance, Usability, and Reliability of a Novel Device for Continuous Collection of Physiological Data in Healthcare and Remote Settings

brief_summary.textblock:
Study objective: The primary objective of the clinical investigation is to evaluate the accuracy of BioStamp nPoint system algorithm measurements.
Study design: A single-site, non-significant risk, open-label, prospective non-randomized clinical investigation designed to validate the accuracy of the various physiological parameters that the Wearable Sensor Patches acquire and the system processes.

primary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of Heart Rate Measured in Beats Per Minute Compared to Reference Device
primary_outcome.description: Heart rate as measured by the subject device in beats per minute will be compared to the reference device. The Mean Absolute Error (MAE) between measurements from each device is presented.

primary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of Heart Rate Variability Measured by Root Mean Square of Successive Differences (HRV RMSSD) Compared to the Reference Device
primary_outcome.description: Heart Rate Variability RMSSD is measured by the subject device determined by root mean square of successive differences in neighboring RR intervals and will be compared to the reference device. The Mean Absolute Error (MAE) between measurements from each device is presented.

primary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of Heart Rate Variability Measured by Low Frequency Content to High Frequency Content Ratio (HRV Ratio) Compared to the Reference Device
primary_outcome.description: HRV Ratio as measured by the subject device determined by low frequency content to high frequency content ratio (HRV Ratio) in beats per minute will be compared to the reference device. The Mean Absolute Error (MAE) between measurements from each device is presented.

primary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of Respiration Rate Measured in Breaths Per Minute Compared to the Reference Device
primary_outcome.description: Respiration rate as measured by the subject device in breaths per minute will be compared to the reference device. The Mean Absolute Error (MAE) between measurements from each device is presented.

primary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of Activity Classification as Compared to Visual Annotation
primary_outcome.description: The device under test will classify a subjects activity into sleeping, standing, sitting, lying, walking and other activities as the subject performs various predefined activities, which are annotated by an observer. The device's Activity Classification will be compared to the observer's annotation. The percentage of correct classifications by the device against indicated visual observation is presented. The percent correct is not a per subject average, but is the percentage of all activity classifications which were correct when compared to ground truth observation.

primary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of Step Count Compared to an Observer's Manual Count
primary_outcome.description: The number of steps reported by the device under test during a 6 minute walk test will be compared to an observer's manual count of the number of steps taken.

primary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of Sleep Onset Time (Hours, Minutes, and Seconds), Sleep Wake Time (Hours, Minutes, and Seconds) as Compared to an Observer's Visual Annotation
primary_outcome.description: Sleep onset and wake times as reported by the device under test will be compared to an observer's visual annotation of the sleep onset and wake times. The Mean Absolute Error (MAE) between times as indicated by the device and observed times is presented.

primary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of Posture Classification as Compared to Visual Annotation
primary_outcome.description: The device under test will classify a subjects activity into sleep posture, standing posture, and sitting posture as the subject performs various predefined activities, which are annotated by an observer. The device's Posture Classification will be compared to the observer's annotation. The percentage of correct classifications by the device against indicated visual observation is presented. The percent correct is not a per subject average, but is the percentage of all posture classifications which were correct when compared to ground truth observation.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Sensors That Remained Sufficiently Adhered to Subjects for 24 Hours as Assessed by a 5 Point Scale
primary_outcome.description: The level of sensor adhesion will be assessed by a 5 point scale (0- sensor is greater than or equal to 90% of sensor adhered, 4-sensor completely detached from subject). Sensors receiving scores of 0 and 1 will be determined to have acceptable adhesion, while scores of 2, 3, and 4 will be considered unacceptable adhesion. The percentage of sensors which had acceptable adhesion at sensor removal is presented.

arm_group.description: This single arm consists of all subjects which will interact with the device under investigation as well as comparator devices. This includes the Physiological signal monitor intervention, Heart rate and heart rate variability comparison device intervention, Respiration rate comparison device intervention, and Activity classification intervention.

intervention.description: Wireless remote monitoring system intended for use by researchers and healthcare professionals for continuous collection of physiological data in home and healthcare settings.

intervention.intervention_name: Heart rate and heart rate variability comparison device
intervention.description: FDA cleared reference device that monitors heart rate and heart rate variability in subjects
FDA cleared reference device that monitors respiration rate in subjects
Visual annotation of subject posture and other activities used for reference

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Participants were recruited via an established database at the clinical site, with the use of IRB approved flyers and posting on the clinical site website. The completely voluntary nature of participation in the study was emphasized. Subject recruitment and screening began July 17, 2017 and completed July 21, 2017.

group.description: This single arm consists of all subjects which will interact with the device under investigation as well as comparator devices. This includes the Physiological signal monitor intervention, Heart rate and heart rate variability comparison device intervention, Respiration rate comparison device intervention, and Activity classification intervention. Heart rate and heart rate variability comparison device: FDA cleared reference device that monitors heart rate and heart rate variability in subjects Respiration rate comparison device: FDA cleared reference device that monitors respiration rate in subjects Activity classification: Visual annotation of subject posture and other activities used for reference

measure.title: Sex: Female, Male
measure.description: Subject sex documented at first visit to the clinic.

measure.title: Race and Ethnicity Not Collected
measure.population: Race and Ethnicity were not collected from any participant.

measure.title: Height (cm)
measure.description: Subject height measured and documented at first visit to the clinic.

measure.title: Weight (kg)
measure.description: Subject weight measured and documented at first visit to the clinic.

measure.title: BMI
measure.description: Subject BMI calculated from subject height and weight.

outcome.title: Accuracy of Heart Rate Measured in Beats Per Minute Compared to Reference Device
outcome.description: Heart rate as measured by the subject device in beats per minute will be compared to the reference device. The Mean Absolute Error (MAE) between measurements from each device is presented.
outcome.population: Once comparator device malfunctioned resulting in a complete loss of Heart Rate data for one subject. All other subjects were analyzed, with n = 24 HR data pairs sampled at random (n = 8 samples each from sleeping, resting, and moving activities) per subject when available.

measure.description: HRV Ratio as measured by the subject device determined by low frequency content to high frequency content ratio (HRV Ratio) in beats per minute will be compared to the reference device. The Mean Absolute Error (MAE) between measurements from each device is presented.

outcome.title: Accuracy of Respiration Rate Measured in Breaths Per Minute Compared to the Reference Device
outcome.description: Respiration rate as measured by the subject device in breaths per minute will be compared to the reference device. The Mean Absolute Error (MAE) between measurements from each device is presented.
outcome.population: All subjects were analyzed, with n = 8 total respiration rate data pairs sampled at random across the two nights of sleep per subject.

group.title: Device Monitoring
group.description: This single arm consists of all subjects which will interact with the device under investigation as well as comparator devices. This includes the Physiological signal monitor intervention, Heart rate and heart rate variability comparison device intervention, Respiration rate comparison device intervention, and Activity classification intervention. Physiological signal monitor: Wireless remote monitoring system intended for use by researchers and healthcare professionals for continuous collection of physiological data in home and healthcare settings. Heart rate and heart rate variability comparison device: FDA cleared reference device that monitors heart rate and heart rate variability in subjects Respiration rate comparison device: FDA cleared reference device that monitors respiration rate in subjects Activity classification: Visual annotation of subject posture and other activities used for reference

measure.title: Accuracy of Respiration Rate Measured in Breaths Per Minute Compared to the Reference Device
measure.description: Respiration rate as measured by the subject device in breaths per minute will be compared to the reference device. The Mean Absolute Error (MAE) between measurements from each device is presented.
measure.population: All subjects were analyzed, with n = 8 total respiration rate data pairs sampled at random across the two nights of sleep per subject.

outcome.title: Accuracy of Activity Classification as Compared to Visual Annotation
outcome.description: The device under test will classify a subjects activity into sleeping, standing, sitting, lying, walking and other activities as the subject performs various predefined activities, which are annotated by an observer. The device's Activity Classification will be compared to the observer's annotation. The percentage of correct classifications by the device against indicated visual observation is presented. The percent correct is not a per subject average, but is the percentage of all activity classifications which were correct when compared to ground truth observation.
outcome.population: All subjects were analyzed, with classifications compared against n = 5 clinician observed one minute long activities (lying, sitting, standing, walking, and stationary biking for "other" classification) per subject. For analysis of sleep classification accuracy, n = 5 one minute long samples were sampled across both nights of sleep per subject.

group.title: Device Monitoring
group.description: This single arm consists of all subjects which will interact with the device under investigation as well as comparator devices. measure.title: Accuracy of Activity Classification as Compared to Visual Annotation
measure.description: The device under test will classify a subjects activity into sleeping, standing, sitting, lying, walking and other activities as the subject performs various predefined activities, which are annotated by an observer. The device's Activity Classification will be compared to the observer's annotation. The percentage of correct classifications by the device against indicated visual observation is presented. The percent correct is not a per subject average, but is the percentage of all activity classifications which were correct when compared to ground truth observation.
measure.population: All subjects were analyzed, with classifications compared against n = 5 clinician observed one minute long activities (lying, sitting, standing, walking, and stationary biking for "other" classification) per subject. For analysis of sleep classification accuracy, n = 5 one minute long samples were sampled across both nights of sleep per subject.

outcome.title: Accuracy of Step Count Compared to an Observer's Manual Count
outcome.description: The number of steps reported by the device under test during a 6 minute walk test will be compared to an observer's manual count of the number of steps taken.
outcome.population: All subjects performed n=5 six minute walk tests on a treadmill. Instances in which the system classified the subject as "walking" for at least 95% of the activity were analyzed. The study device step count was compared to the manually observed step count, with the percent error of each test calculated. These errors were averaged and are presented.

group.title: Device Monitoring
group.description: This single arm consists of all subjects which will interact with the device under investigation as well as comparator devices. This includes the Physiological signal monitor intervention, Heart rate and heart rate variability comparison device intervention, Respiration rate comparison device intervention, and Activity classification intervention. Physiological signal monitor: Wireless remote monitoring system intended for use by researchers and healthcare professionals for continuous collection of physiological data in home and healthcare settings. Heart rate and heart rate variability comparison device: FDA cleared reference device that monitors heart rate and heart rate variability in subjects Respiration rate comparison device: FDA cleared reference device that monitors respiration rate in subjects Activity classification: Visual annotation of subject posture and other activities used for reference

measure.title: Accuracy of Step Count Compared to an Observer's Manual Count
measure.description: The number of steps reported by the device under test during a 6 minute walk test will be compared to an observer's manual count of the number of steps taken.
measure.population: All subjects performed n=5 six minute walk tests on a treadmill. Instances in which the system classified the subject as "walking" for at least 95% of the activity were analyzed. The study device step count was compared to the manually observed step count, with the percent error of each test calculated. These errors were averaged and are presented.

outcome.title: Accuracy of Sleep Onset Time (Hours, Minutes, and Seconds), Sleep Wake Time (Hours, Minutes, and Seconds) as Compared to an Observer's Visual Annotation
outcome.description: Sleep onset and wake times as reported by the device under test will be compared to an observer's visual annotation of the sleep onset and wake times. The Mean Absolute Error (MAE) between times as indicated by the device and observed times is presented.
outcome.population: All subjects were analyzed, with n = 2 sleep onset and n = 2 sleep wake times compared per subject against sleep technician observations

group.title: Device Monitoring
group.description: This single arm consists of all subjects which will interact with the device under investigation as well as comparator devices. This includes the Physiological signal monitor intervention, Heart rate and heart rate variability comparison device intervention, Respiration rate comparison device intervention, and Activity classification intervention. Physiological signal monitor: Wireless remote monitoring system intended for use by researchers and healthcare professionals for continuous collection of physiological data in home and healthcare settings. Heart rate and heart rate variability comparison device: FDA cleared reference device that monitors heart rate and heart rate variability in subjects Respiration rate comparison device: FDA cleared reference device that monitors respiration rate in subjects Activity classification: Visual annotation of subject posture and other activities used for reference

measure.title: Accuracy of Sleep Onset Time (Hours, Minutes, and Seconds), Sleep Wake Time (Hours, Minutes, and Seconds) as Compared to an Observer's Visual Annotation
measure.description: Sleep onset and wake times as reported by the device under test will be compared to an observer's visual annotation of the sleep onset and wake times. The Mean Absolute Error (MAE) between times as indicated by the device and observed times is presented.
measure.population: All subjects were analyzed, with n = 2 sleep onset and n = 2 sleep wake times compared per subject against sleep technician observations

outcome.title: Accuracy of Posture Classification as Compared to Visual Annotation
outcome.description: The device under test will classify a subjects activity into sleep posture, standing posture, and sitting posture as the subject performs various predefined activities, which are annotated by an observer. The device's Posture Classification will be compared to the observer's annotation. The percentage of correct classifications by the device against indicated visual observation is presented. The percent correct is not a per subject average, but is the percentage of all posture classifications which were correct when compared to ground truth observation.
outcome.population: All subjects were analyzed, with each subject completing n = 5 repetitions of each sleeping / lying (supine, prone, lying left, lying right) and sitting / standing (upright, leaning backward, leaning forward, leaning left, leaning right) postures.

group.title: Device Monitoring
group.description: This single arm consists of all subjects which will interact with the device under investigation as well as comparator devices. This includes the Physiological signal monitor intervention, Heart rate and heart rate variability comparison device intervention, Respiration rate comparison device intervention, and Activity classification intervention. Physiological signal monitor: Wireless remote monitoring system intended for use by researchers and healthcare professionals for continuous collection of physiological data in home and healthcare settings. Heart rate and heart rate variability comparison device: FDA cleared reference device that monitors heart rate and heart rate variability in subjects Respiration rate comparison device: FDA cleared reference device that monitors respiration rate in subjects Activity classification: Visual annotation of subject posture and other activities used for reference

measure.title: Accuracy of Posture Classification as Compared to Visual Annotation
measure.description: The device under test will classify a subjects activity into sleep posture, standing posture, and sitting posture as the subject performs various predefined activities, which are annotated by an observer. The device's Posture Classification will be compared to the observer's annotation. The percentage of correct classifications by the device against indicated visual observation is presented. The percent correct is not a per subject average, but is the percentage of all posture classifications which were correct when compared to ground truth observation.
measure.population: All subjects were analyzed, with each subject completing n = 5 repetitions of each sleeping / lying (supine, prone, lying left, lying right) and sitting / standing (upright, leaning backward, leaning forward, leaning left, leaning right) postures.

outcome.title: Number of Sensors That Remained Sufficiently Adhered to Subjects for 24 Hours as Assessed by a 5 Point Scale
outcome.description: The level of sensor adhesion will be assessed by a 5 point scale (0- sensor is greater than or equal to 90% of sensor adhered, 4-sensor completely detached from subject). Sensors receiving scores of 0 and 1 will be determined to have acceptable adhesion, while scores of 2, 3, and 4 will be considered unacceptable adhesion. The percentage of sensors which had acceptable adhesion at sensor removal is presented.
outcome.population: All subjects analyzed, with 6 sensor locations per subject evaluated for adhesion to skin at device removal. Subjects wore n = 4 sensors (two sensors at chest and thigh locations required for algorithmic outputs, and one sensor at shank and one at forearm locations) on Day 1 and n = 2 sensors (chest and thigh algorithm location sensors) on Day 2.

group.title: Device Monitoring
group.description: This single arm consists of all subjects which will interact with the device under investigation as well as comparator devices. measure.description: The level of sensor adhesion will be assessed by a 5 point scale (0- sensor is greater than or equal to 90% of sensor adhered, 4-sensor completely detached from subject). Sensors receiving scores of 0 and 1 will be determined to have acceptable adhesion, while scores of 2, 3, and 4 will be considered unacceptable adhesion. The percentage of sensors which had acceptable adhesion at sensor removal is presented.
measure.population: All subjects analyzed, with 6 sensor locations per subject evaluated for adhesion to skin at device removal. Subjects wore n = 4 sensors (two sensors at chest and thigh locations required for algorithmic outputs, and one sensor at shank and one at forearm locations) on Day 1 and n = 2 sensors (chest and thigh algorithm location sensors) on Day 2.

class.title: Sensors for Algorithm Outputs (Chest and Thigh)

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse event data was available for collection for 3 days after the subject left the clinic. Subjects were evaluated throughout their 3 days at the clinic and a safety follow up phone call was conducted 3 days after their last clinic visit.
reported_events.desc: All adverse events (all-cause mortality, serious, and non-serious) were collected. The study was inherently low risk, as the test device is a non-significant risk device and study population was limited to healthy volunteers.

group.title: Device Monitoring
group.description: This single arm consists of all subjects which will interact with the device under investigation as well as comparator devices. This includes the Physiological signal monitor intervention, Heart rate and heart rate variability comparison device intervention, Respiration rate comparison device intervention, and Activity classification intervention. Physiological signal monitor: Wireless remote monitoring system intended for use by researchers and healthcare professionals for continuous collection of physiological data in home and healthcare settings. Heart rate and heart rate variability comparison device: FDA cleared reference device that monitors heart rate and heart rate variability in subjects Respiration rate comparison device: FDA cleared reference device that monitors respiration rate in subjects Activity classification: Visual annotation of subject posture and other activities used for reference

event.description: A single non-serious adverse event was reported during the evaluation period. A subject self reported mild nasal congestion after spending the night at the clinical site. This was deemed unrelated to the test device.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: This study design was based off of the predicate device's pivotal study design. It was limited to healthy subjects only.
